Human small intestine 6-7 m long Duodenum 20-30 cm Jejunum 2.5 m Ileum 3.5 m
Fig. 7-2 Granger, D, et al. Clinical Gastrointestinal Physiology. W.B. Saunders, Philadelphia, PA; 1985: 144.
[H1] Histologic organization of the small intestinal mucosa.
"Functional morphology of the mucosa of the small intestine".
[LIST_ITEM] Normal American diet contains 200-300 g (50% of caloric intake)
[LIST_ITEM] Serves an energy and carbon source
[LIST_ITEM] Digestion includes a luminal phase and a brush border phase
[LIST_ITEM] Amylase (pH optima 7) cleaves interior α1-4 linkages but not α1-6
[LIST_ITEM] Endproduct is a mixture of maltose, maltotriose and limit dextrans
[H1] Intestinal Brush Border Phase of Carbohydrate Digestion.
[H2] Intestinal Brush Border Hydrolysis of Oligosaccharides.

|  Enzyme | Substrates | Molecular Site of Hydrolysis | Products  | | --- | --- | --- | --- | |  Maltase | Maltose, maltotriose | α-1,4 linkage | glucose  | |  Sucrase* | Sucrose | α-1,4 linkage | glucose, fructose  | |  Lactase | Lactose | β-1,4 linkage (but not of cellulose) | glucose, galactose  | |  α-Dextrinase (isomaltase) | α-Limit dextrins | α-1,6 linkage | glucose, maltose, oligosaccharides  |
*Sucrase is also very active against maltose and maltotriose.
Fig. 7-15 Granger, D, et al. Clinical Gastrointestinal Physiology. W.B. Saunders, Philadelphia, PA; 1985: 169.
Lactase is present in infancy by disappears to a variable extent during childhood in most humans.
Exception is Northern Europeans and European Americans-commonly retain lactase into adulthood.
[LIST_ITEM] Normal humans require about 0.75 g/kg body weight of high quality dietary protein daily
[LIST_ITEM] Nine essential amino acids are not synthesized and must be obtained from diet
Also endogenous protein in digestive secretions and shed epithelial cells
[LIST_ITEM] Digestion includes a luminal and brush border phase
[LIST_ITEM] Both amino acids and di- and tri-peptides absorbed
Fig. 11-8 Johnson, L. Gastrointestinal Physiology, 7th ed. Mosby Elsevier, Philadelphia, PA; 2007: 114.
Fig 7-18 Granger, D, et al. Clinical Gastrointestinal Physiology. W.B. Saunders, Philadelphia, PA; 1985: 174.
Peptidases ~20 Including enterokinase Endo-; amino; carboxyl etc
Di & tri Peptides H+ coupled PepT1
Protein Digestion 1 luminal (stomach, pancreas) 2 brush border (enterocyte) 3 intracellular (enterocyte)
Small amounts of peptides enter blood intact- may be important in immune response
[H1] Defects in Absorption of Protein Digestion.
[H2] Products due to Altered Transport Systems in Gut and Kidney.
[LIST_ITEM] Increased excretion in urine with renal stones
[LIST_ITEM] Impaired absorption of neutral amino acids
Patients normally don't show protein malnutrition- di and tri peptides sufficient
[LIST_ITEM] Normal American diet about 100g/day primarily as triglyceride
[LIST_ITEM] Long chain "essential" polyunsaturated fatty acids, cholesterol, and fat soluble vitamins also present
[LIST_ITEM] Lipid digestion begins in stomach and is completed in upper intestine in the lumen
[LIST_ITEM] Multiple lipase enzymes have pH optima between 6 and 7
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Emulsification physical process takes place in stomach phospholipids, proteins facilitate
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Solubilization requires bile salts role of mixed micelles
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Absorption normally <5gm in stool- more is “steatorrhea”
pH optimum 6-7 in presence of bile salts acid inactivates
Fig. 8 Johnson, L. Essential Medical Physiology New York Raven Press 1992: 515.
Mixed micelles solubilize the products of lipid digestion.
Colipase anchors lipase to the fat droplet in the presence of bile salts.
[H1] Ways to alter fat digestion and absorption.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Olestra - Fake fat, can't be digested
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Orlistat (Xenical) – Covalent Lipase inhibitor Now available OTC as Alli
Side effect of both is malabsorption and diarrhea
[H1] Lipid Absorption in the Small Intestine.
Short and medium chain fatty acids as well as glycerol
Fig. 11-14 Johnson, L. Gastrointestinal Physiology, 6th ed. Mosby Elsevier, St. Louis, MO; 2001: 136.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Fatty acids are 6-12 carbons in chain length
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Present in small amounts in normal diet
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Can be digested and absorbed without bile salts due to increased water solubility
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Fatty acids not reesterified but taken up into the portal vein
[LIST_ITEM] Luminal cholesterol comes largely from diet and bile; about 50% absorbed by intestine
[LIST_ITEM] Cholesterol absorbed selectively as compared to plant sterols
[LIST_ITEM] Absorbed cholesterol released in chylomicron and goes back to liver as chylomicron remnants
[LIST_ITEM] Ezetimibe (Zetia) is a new drug that blocks cholesterol entry into the enterocyte
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Dietary intake about 1000 mg/day with net absorption of about 100 mg/day
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Most active in duodenum and involves an energy dependent, transcellular pathway
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Regulated by active form of Vit D, 1,25(OH)₂ Vit D, also known as 1,25(OH)₂-cholecalciferol
Fig. 9 Chang, E, Sitrin, M, Black, D. Gastrointestinal, Hepatobiliary, and Nutritional Physiology. Lippincott - Raven, Philadelphia, PA; 1996: 204.
[H1] MOLECULAR COMPONENTS OF INTESTINAL CALCIUM ABSORPTION.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Entry across the apical brush border is mediated by a specific $\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}$ entry channel known as CaT1
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Within the enterocyte a calcium binding protein, calbindin binds and transports $\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}$
[NUMBERED_ITEM] $\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}$ exit across the basolateral membrane is mediated by the plasma membrane $\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}$ATPase, PMCA1
[H1] Synthesis and Action of Vitamin D.
Fig. 12-6 Johnson, L. Gastrointestinal Physiology, 7th ed. Mosby Elsevier, Philadelphia, PA; 2007: 133.
[H1] Volumes and ionic composition of fluid entering the human intestine.
[LIST_ITEM] Mucosa is leaky allowing rapid osmotic equilibration of hypertonic and hypotonic meals
[LIST_ITEM] Duodenal secretion of $\mathrm{HCO}_3^-$ from Brunner's glands
[LIST_ITEM] Absorption by small intestine is then isotonic
[H1] Cellular Models of Intestinal Sodium Absorption.
Fig. 7-7 and 7-8 from Granger, D, et al. Clinical Gastrointestinal Physiology. W.B. Saunders, Philadelphia, PA; 1985.
Can be regulated by contents, neurotransmitters, inflammatory mediators and systemic hormones particularly Angiotensin II
[H1] Fluid Absorption According to the Standing Osmotic Gradient Model.
Can account for isotonic movement Of fluid by use of localized hypertonicity
Fig. 12-4 Johnson, L. Gastrointestinal Physiology, 7th ed. Mosby Elsevier, Philadelphia, PA; 2007.
[H1] ION TRANSPORT BY INTESTINAL VILLUS AND CRYPT CELLS.
Is due to Cholera Toxin activating
INDUCERS OF COLONIC AND SMALL INTESTINAL SECRETION
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Mixing of foodstuffs, digestive secretions and enzymes
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Facilitate contact of chyme with intestinal mucosa
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Net propulsion in an aboral direction
[H1] Intraluminal Pressure Changes in the Duodenum of a Concious Man.
Fig. 5-1 Johnson, L. Gastrointestinal Physiology,  $7^{\text{th}}$  ed. Mosby Elsevier, Philadelphia, PA; 2007: 42.
In duodenum contractions occur at intervals of 5 sec or multiples of 5
[H1] Electrical Threshold for Generation of Action Potentials.
Frequency of slow waves is 12/min in duodenum and decreases to 9/min in The ileum. (Another site of pacemaker activity)
Fed pattern initiated by the Presence of chyme in the intestine
Villus contraction which increases after a meal also helps mix unstirred layer and compress the lacteal
Isolated segmental contractions serve to mix the intestinal contents.
Only very short peristaltic movements occur in the fed state
Contractions that have an orad-to-aborad sequence (left-to-right) serve to propel contents in a net aboral direction.
Fig. 5-3 Johnson, L. Gastrointestinal Physiology, 7th ed. Mosby Elsevier, Philadelphia, PA; 2007: 44.
[H1] Relationship between Plasma Motilin and the MMC.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Required to maintain normal physiology and health
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Occur in diet, sometimes as trace elements
[NUMBERED_ITEM] In steady state intestinal absorption equals body losses
